As ever, there are plenty of visuals to convey the points being made. Getting mobile page height right has long been tricky, but these new units make things more manageable and browser support is good too, which makes a niceÂ change.

items.content:
#â€‹600 â€” July 5, 2023 | Read on the web

A Deep Dive Into SVG Paths â€” This is a very well presented interactive guide to understanding SVG paths and path commands, covering cursors, lines, bÃ©zier curves, andÂ more. The inline comments are a neat feature offering extra context, and the creator is looking to release a more complete Interactive SVG Animations course later thisÂ year.

Nanda Syahrasyad

ğŸ’¡ In our Code and Tools section (below) we also link to SvgPathEditor, a handy minimal in-browser SVG path editor.

New Course: The Hard Parts of UI Development â€” Develop an under-the-hood knowledge of UI development by learning techniques such as data binding, UI composition, templating, virtual DOM and its reconciliation, and hooks, all fromÂ scratch!

Frontend Masters sponsor

Useful DevTools Tips and Tricks â€” Having worked on the developer tools in both Firefox and Edge, Patrick knows his stuff (he's shared over 100 tips on his tips site). In this post, he shares his topÂ 15, including disabling event listeners, copying element styles, visualising a page in 3D, and even changing the language of DevTools itself.

Patrick Brosset (Microsoft)

In Defence of DOMContentLoaded â€” A solid explainer on measuring browser events and the use cases for DOMContentLoaded (and its related events) in particular. "The DOMContentLoaded event fires once all of your deferred JavaScript has finishedÂ running."

Harry Roberts

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Version 115 of Firefox is out now adding hardware video decoding for Intel GPUs onÂ Linux.

  • Rachel Andrew's is back with her monthly round-up of what's new on the web platform (in June 2023, in thisÂ case).

  • Here are the release notes for Safari Technology Preview 173, which adds a new feature flags section, JPEG XL support, a new responsive design mode, and more.

  • In an effort to 'prevent fraud' the French government wants to inject state-operated domain blocking lists directly into browsers. ğŸ¤”

  • Ethernet is 50 years young. Here's why it has endured as the ubiquitous data framing protocol for half a century.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

What Does the decoding Attribute on Images Do? â€” An in-depth look at what the decoding attribute sets out to do, the nuance behind it, how it may have some performance gains in certain circumstances, and whether to consider it as part of your overall image renderingÂ strategy.

Barry Pollard

An Introduction to the View Transitions API â€” The experimental View Transitions API offers an easier way to animate between DOM states and even between page loads. Hereâ€™s a look at how to use this progressiveÂ enhancement.

Craig Buckler

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor

â–¶Â Â State of the CSS Community â€” A talk from the recent CSS Day event in Amsterdam, highlighting the current excitement around CSS and the slew of new features that weâ€™ve seen come to the web platform over the past fewÂ years.

Una Kravets

First-Person Scrollers â€” Thereâ€™s something of a parallel between videogames and browser engines when it comes to them both having to maintain a solid, smooth frame rate. Eric notes how the evolution of web technologies and fresh new ideas, has to be balanced with meeting performance and rendering considerations. (I also just like the Halo-inspired UIÂ here.)

Eric Meyer

â–¶Â Â The Trick to Smoothly Animating Shadows in CSS â€” Animating a shadow can often be tricky as itâ€™s heavy on performance, but it can be important for maintaining a realistic sense of depth. Kevin shares a solution in just fiveÂ minutes.

Kevin Powell

"I Made 7 Predictions for the Web for the Next 5 Years" â€” A mixed bag of hits and misses here, but always fun to check in on some priorÂ predictions.

Fagner Brack

How to Use CSS background-size and background-position
Ralph Mason

Creating SVG Animations with Tailwind CSS
Mbaziira Ronald

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

SvgPathEditor: Edit and Save SVG Path Data â€” Lets you adjust all sorts of configuration and path settings while interactively adjusting the path via nodes in theÂ browser. Could be handy for creating adhoc bits of SVG.

Yann Armelin

Hurl 4.0.0: Powerful CLI HTTP Request Scripting â€” A powerful command line tool that runs HTTP requests written (scripted, really) in a plain text format. It can also be used to test HTTP responses and you can use variables to carry over elements of a response into a fresh request. It just hit versionÂ 4.0.

Orange

Minimal CLS Font Adjustment: A Tool to Automatically Match the Fallback Font for Improving CLS â€” By now youâ€™ve likely heard of 'cumulative layout shift' (a.k.a. CLS) and all its drawbacks. This tool aims to help you find matching fallback fonts to minimize the issue. It uses the size-adjust CSS descriptor for the @font-face at rule. (Note: Not supported in SafariÂ yet.)

Malte Ubl

Automize: The Missing Chrome DevTools Element Selector â€” Claims to offer a â€˜more intuitiveâ€™ GUI inside your devtools to make it easier to target deeply-nested elements, and works with test frameworks like Puppeteer, Playwright, Cypress, andÂ Selenium.

Automize

Zero-Runtime CSS with Vanilla Extract â€” Vanilla Extract is an alternative to CSS-in-JS (if that's your bag) that allows writing zero-runtimeÂ CSS in TypeScript. "Basically, itâ€™s â€œCSS Modules-in-TypeScriptâ€ but with scoped CSS Variables + heaps more."

Leonardo Maldonado

Creating a Ferris Wheel with Just CSS â€” Fancy a trip to the fair without even having to stand up? This is a neat, animated demo made using onlyÂ CSS. (Take care: it seems quite resource intensive.)

Amit Sheen codepen

items.content:
#â€‹599 â€” June 28, 2023 | Read on the web

ğŸ”® Future CSS: State Container Queries? â€” The Chromium team is experimenting with a new type of CSS container query: state queries. These let you define styles based upon the state of another element (such as whether a position: sticky-ed element is actually 'stuck' and how). Itâ€™s early days and Chrome Canary only for now, but this is a good initial look at theÂ concept.

Ahmad Shadeed

Introducing the MDN Playground â€” The popular Web dev docs site has branched out a little into the world of code sandboxes. The MDN Playground provides a space to prototype frontend ideas and expand live samples in the MDN docs into more of an interactiveÂ experience.

Mozilla

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Create signup and login forms, reset passwords, generate magic links, add SSO with Google, and more. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor

Behind the Curtains of Wikipedia's Redesign â€” Shipping a redesign of one of the most visited sites on the web is no mean feat. Here, Alex Hollender and Jon Robson (from the team behind the effort) share details on the design, development, and process that went into theÂ project.

Geoff Graham INTERVIEW

Going Beyond Constants with Custom Properties â€” Some insights as to how we can use custom properties to â€œcreate some smart systems or even use them as booleans in CSS and create easy progressiveÂ enhancementsâ€.

Brecht De Ruyte

  • Two version 4s this week, with Svelte 4.0 (the frontend framework) and Stencil 4.0 (the Web Components toolchain) both landing.

  • Support for the CSS @property at rule may be enabled in Firefox Nightly soon. Firefox has long been a hold out in browser support for this feature.

  • Alvaro Montoro is having fun creating single div CSS drawings. We like the Spirited Away and Game Boy pieces. One to use Inspect ElementÂ on.

All experimental stuff, but an excellent bit of testing with examples to play withÂ too.

courierâ€¤com sponsor

Form and Search Landmarks â€” A look at how well browsers and screen readers support the form and search landmark ARIAÂ roles.

Manuel MatuzoviÄ‡

Modern CSS in Real Life â€” Chris (of CodePen fame) runs through five modern CSS concepts that â€œreally matter to real-world developmentâ€, including logical properties, container queries, color spaces, and more. This is a real deep-dive highlighting the fast-paced changes we are seeing in CSS, with plenty of code, examples, and visuals to help thingsÂ along.

Chris Coyier

The 'State of CSS 2023' Survey is NowÂ Open â€” With a ton of new CSS features like :has(), subgrid, and container queries quickly gaining adoption the annual CSS survey from Devographics returns a bit earlier than usual. Hereâ€™s the announcement post explaining why you should fill itÂ out, and some background from this year's lead survey designer, Chen Hui Jing. It's well explained but CSS custom properties are twisted â€“ nay, broken up â€“ into new shapes that it might take a little head scratching to figureÂ out.

Roman Komarov

  • The W3C has deployed its new website.

Hidde looks at what options we have to resolveÂ this.

Hidde de Vries

Thoughts from â€œMeet Safari for Spatial Computingâ€ â€” The key takeaway being that when it comes to visionOS you can continue doing â€œwhat responsive web design and accessibility experts have advocated for yearsâ€, and for the most part things will â€˜just workâ€™ on this newÂ platform.

Jim Nielsen

The New CSS â€” How recent tooling changes and new capabilities represent a â€œfundamental shiftâ€ for CSS, making it â€œnow the most powerful design tool for theÂ Webâ€.

Matthias Ott

Notion sponsor

Fit-to-Width Text â€” An active look at how scroll-driven animations will hopefully solve the â€˜fit-to-widthâ€™ text problem with just pureÂ CSS. (See also: This collection of related demos from Bramus Van Damme.)

Roman Komarov

â–¶Â Â Going Beyond Color Contrast â€” A quick introduction to tools that will help you automate the identification of accessibility issues beyond color contrast. Thereâ€™s an accompanying blog post too.

Schalk Neethling

â–¶Â Â Improving Performance for Three Million Sites â€” An interesting dig into how Shopify approaches performance challenges atÂ scale.

Michael Gooding

The :has() psuedo-class selector

The :has() CSS pseudo-class now enjoys widespread browser support, and can be used across Chrome, Safari, Edge, Opera, and others (Firefox has it behind a flag for now). It lets you style an element that contains a specific descendant, defined by a selector argument, and can be used in a variety of interesting, creative ways.

Stephanie Eckles

Using :has() as a CSS 'Parent Selector' and More â€” Jen runs through the basics of how to use :has() as a parent selector with some practical examples. â€œThis feels like a revolution in how we will write CSS selectors...â€
Jen Simmons (WebKit)

The Advanced Guide to the CSS :has() Selector â€” Rahul looks at some advanced implementations and use cases for has, including checking for multiple children, conditional decorations, and styling emptyÂ states.
Rahul Chhodde

Style Your RSS Feed â€” How to make your RSS feed look nice (thanks to XSLT) and provide useful information at the sameÂ time.
Darek Kay

How to Watch Transitions in Slow Motion in Chromeâ€™s DevTools
Jim Nielsen

Six Quick Tests You Can Do to Test Your Forms for Accessibility
Karl Groves

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Frosted Glass â€” A lovely looking depth-based blur effect created with CSS. Hereâ€™s how it works, and some otherÂ examples.

Shu Ding

Motion Canvas: A TypeScript Library and Real-Time Preview Editor to Program Animations â€” Uses generator functions to procedurally define your animations, and you can try out the web-based editor that allows you to work with the animationsÂ visually.

Motion Canvas

SVG.js v3.2: SVG Manipulation and Animation Library â€” A lightweight approach without dependencies. Thereâ€™s a demo on JSFiddle you can play with. GitHubÂ repo.

Various Authors

Code Together Before You Work Together. Interview Devs in a RealÂ IDE â€” Skip algorithm interviews & use CoderPad to run coding interviews that are trusted by both candidates andÂ interviewers.

CoderPad sponsor

daisyUI: A Library of Tailwind CSS Components in MultipleÂ Themes â€” Includes dozens of ready-made components that you can try out using about 20 different themes, all of which are testable live in theÂ docs.

Redfern Dev

Threlte: A Three.js Scene Renderer and Component Library forÂ Svelte â€” react-three-fiber is great, but if you prefer Svelte, this is the alternative for you. It appears to be under very active development too with a whole new version on the way soon. GitHubÂ repo.

Grischa Erbe

Microsoft Clarity: Free Heatmaps & Session Recordings â€” A new, free user behavior analytics tool, that claims to be both GDPR & CCPA compliant â€”Â it helps visualize how users are interacting with your site through session replays andÂ heatmaps. Why is it free? Curiously, MS is upfront aboutÂ that.

Microsoft

Novel: A Notion-Style WYSIWYG Editor with AI-Powered Autocompletions â€” Built with Next.js, Tiptap, OpenAI (for autocomplete), and Tailwind. Try it liveÂ here.

Steven Tey
